## First of all
::: {.callout-tip}
## Education is a universal right
<q>*Everyone has the right to education. Education shall be free, at least in the elementary and fundamental stages. Elementary education shall be compulsory. Technical and professional education shall be made generally available and higher education shall be equally accessible to all on the basis of merit*</q> <br><br>
Source: [Universal Declaration of Human Rights](https://www.un.org/sites/un2.un.org/files/2021/03/udhr.pdf) as declared by the United Nations in 1948.
:::

# A bit about human intelligence

## What is human intelligence?
::: {.callout-tip appearance="simple"}
Human intelligence is the ability to learn, reason, solve problems and adapt to new situations
:::

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
1. Human intelligence is not unidimensional: 

  - Cognitive abilities: memory, logic, problem solving, etc.
  - Emotional intelligence: such as empathy and self-awareness

2. Human intelligence is the result of careful integration of our senses, emotions, and cognitive abilities
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
![](https://askabiologist.asu.edu/sites/default/files/resources/articles/nervous_journey/brain-regions-areas.gif)
:::
:::: 

## How do humans learn?

There are multiple forms of learning:

1. Experiential learning: Learning through direct experience with an emphasis on reflection and application
2. Social learning: Learning through observation and interaction with others with an emphasis on social context and collaboration
3. Symbolic learning: Using language and numbers to convey information

::: {.callout-tip}
## Neuroplasticity is key
Neuroplasticity is the brain's ability to reorganize itself by forming new neural pathways throughout life.

- **Neurplasticity is crucial for learning and memory**. It allows the brain to adapt to new experiences. 
::: 

## What does our brain need?
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](img/exercise.png)
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](https://images.theconversation.com/files/70762/original/image-20150202-25924-ovcp6p.jpg?ixlib=rb-4.1.0&rect=0%2C103%2C994%2C778&q=45&auto=format&w=926&fit=clip)
:::
::::

::: {.footer}
[Marzola P, Melzer T, Pavesi E, Gil-Mohapel J, Brocardo PS. Exploring the Role of Neuroplasticity in Development, Aging, and Neurodegeneration. Brain Sci. 13(12):1610.](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/38137058/)
:::

## What does our brain want?
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](img/effort.png)
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:1400/format:webp/1*c8FZRIUvbDLyiFn9ylIQ0A.png)
:::
::::

We all (i.e. worldwide) seem to have an intrinsic motivation to avoid cognitive effort. 

- The larger the cognitive effort, the larger the aversion to it.

::: {.footer}
[David, L., Vassena, E., & Bijleveld, E. (2024). The unpleasantness of thinking: A meta-analytic review of the association between mental effort and negative affect. Psychological Bulletin.](https://psycnet.apa.org/doi/10.1037/bul0000443)
:::

:::

## Cogito ergo sum

![](img/descartes.webp)


## Conclusion
The way that humans learn has not changed. The tools that we have at our disposal, however, are becoming more plentiful.  We should be careful in implementing these tools into student learning, as they may pose a threat to our cognitive relevance. 

Teaching students how to leverage their own work and creativity is a prime goal for the future of education. 

Teaching our community to replace their own thinking with AI tools will limit the potential of our scientific effort and our intellectual property.

::: {.callout-tip}
Use generative AI tools to extend your capabilities, not to replace them. AI is IMO not part of the human evolution process. 
:::
